questions.text: A 45-year-old male, with a recent stroke complaint of right upper and lower limb weakness, and sensory disturbance. Language assessment reveals non fluent, labored, dysarthric, and telegraphic. The patient has good comprehension but is agrammatic. Fluency, naming, and repetition are impaired. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Motor aphasia The patient's Repetition is impaired with nonfluent , labored, dysarthric, agrammatism, and telegraphic The patient also has an additional neurologic deficit hemiparesis. This is a case of Broca’s aphasia or motor aphasia. A combination of sensory disturbance, motor weakness, and nonfluent aphasia suggests that an embolus has occluded the proximal superior division and infarcted large portions of the frontal and parietal cortices, including an infarction of Broca’s area (the inferior frontal convolution)

Impaired Normal Preserved Isolation /mixed transcortical aphasia Motor+ sensory speech association area Impaired Normal Affected (Echolalia) Global aphasia All areas Impaired Impaired Impaired Anomic aphasia Dominant hemisphere Normal Normal Normal Note- Naming is affected in all forms of Aphasia.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A.In sensory aphasia or Wernicke's aphasia - fluency is preserved or increased , while comprehension, repetition, and naming are impaired . Option: C. In conduction aphasia , comprehension and fluency Are preserved while repetition and naming are impaired. Option: D. In global aphasia , all 4 characters of speech, c omprehension, fluency, repetition, and naming are impaired .

Extraedge:

A combination of sensory disturbance, motor weakness, and nonfluent aphasia(Broca’s Aphasia) suggests that an embolus has occluded the proximal superior division and infarcted large portions of the frontal and parietal cortices. If a fluent (Wernicke’s) aphasia occurs without weakness, the inferior division of the MCA supplying the posterior part (temporal cortex) of the dominant hemisphere is probably involved. Jargon speech and an inability to comprehend written and spoken language are prominent features, often accompanied by a contralateral, homonymous superior quadrantanopia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with CVA, jargon speech, paraphrastic errors, and neologism and his comprehension was impaired. The patient got irritated when the physician couldn't understand his speech. The common arteries involved are all except?

options.label: A
options.text: Superior division of middle cerebral artery

options.label: B
options.text: Inferior division of middle cerebral artery

questions.correct_answer: A. Superior division of middle cerebral artery
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Superior division of middle cerebral artery Supplies Broca’s area and The clinical scenario is suggestive of Wernicke’s aphasia as Patient’s comprehension is impaired , this means the ability to grasp the meaning of spoken words and sentences is impaired in this patient. The doctor cannot understand the patient This is a characteristic feature in Wernicke’s aphasia, where paraphasic errors may lead to a string of neologisms , which leads to ‘jargon aphasia’ The doctor noting the increase in the fluency of the patient also points towards the diagnosis of Wernicke’s aphasia , where the output is voluminous but uninformative . The lesion site most commonly associated with Wernicke’s aphasia caused by CVAs is the posterior portion of the language network. An embolus to the inferior division of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) , to the posterior temporal or angular branches in particular, is the most common etiology. Intracerebral hemorrhage, head trauma, and neoplasm are other causes of Wernicke’s aphasia.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with a recent CVA involving the temporoparietal region complains that he cannot read loud, but can comprehend the context. Language assessment reveals naming and repetition impaired but fluency is preserved. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Conduction aphasia Impaired repetition with preserved fluency, Reading aloud is impaired , but reading comprehension is preserved in this patient suggests Conduction aphasia Speech output is fluent but contains many phonemic paraphasias , -The responsible lesion, usually a CVA in the temporoparietal or dorsal perisylvian region , interferes with the function of the phonological loop interconnecting Broca’s area with Wernicke’s area.

Highyeild:

Impaired Normal Preserved Isolation /mixed transcortical aphasia Motor+ sensory speech association area Impaired Normal Affected (Echolalia) Global aphasia All areas Impaired Impaired Impaired Anomic aphasia Dominant hemisphere Normal Normal Normal Classification of cortical speech problems. (1) Wernicke's aphasia: fluent dysphasia with poor comprehension and poor repetition. (2) Conduction aphasia: fluent aphasia with good comprehension and poor repetition. (3) Broca's aphasia: non-fluent aphasia with good comprehension and poor repetition. (4) Transcortical sensory aphasia: fluent aphasia with poor comprehension and good repetition. (5) Transcortical motor aphasia: non-fluent aphasia with good comprehension and good repetition. Large lesions affecting all of regions 1-5 cause global aphasia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male alcoholic was stuck in a fire accident, a few days back and presented with impaired comprehension and naming with no purposeful speech but echolalia was present. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Isolation aphasia The clinical scenario suggests Isolation aphasia as both fluency and comprehension is affected by Echolalia(Intact repetition). The fire accident may lead to the accumulation of carbon monoxide in the blood leading to isolation aphasia. Isolation aphasia represents a combination of the two transcortical aphasias . Only repetition is preserved in isolation aphasia. Comprehension is severely impaired, and there is no purposeful speech output. -The patient may parrot fragments of heard conversations (echolalia), indicating that the neural mechanisms for repetition are at least partially intact. -Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas tend to be spared, but there is damage to the surrounding frontal, parietal, and temporal cortex. Lesions are patchy and can be associated with anoxia , carbon monoxide poisoning , or complete watershed zone infarcts .

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with dementia. Language assessment revealed intact articulation, comprehension, and repetition but naming is impaired. This type of aphasia is seen in all except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Viral encephalitis The clinical scenario suggests a case of anomic aphasia. Comprehension, Repetition, and speech fluency are intact with impaired Naming . Anomic aphasia may be seen in all the above cases except viral encephalitis.

Highyeild:

Anomic aphasia “minimal dysfunction” syndrome of the language network. Articulation, comprehension, and repetition are intact Confrontation naming, word finding, and spelling are impaired. Word-finding pauses are uncommon, so language output is fluent but paraphasic, circumlocutious, and uninformative. The lesion sites can be anywhere within the left hemisphere language network, including the middle and inferior temporal gyri. Anomic aphasia is the single most common language disturbance seen in Head trauma Metabolic encephalopathy Alzheimer’s disease.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A, B, and D cause Anomic aphasia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents acutely with CVA of the angular gyrus in the left hemisphere. A differential diagnosis of Gerstmann syndrome was kept. What are the features of this syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Semantic paraphasia is not a feature of Gerstmann syndrome.

Highyeild:

Gerstmann’s Syndrome - The combination of Acalculia (impairment of simple arithmetic) Dysgraphia (impaired writing) Finger anomia (an inability to name individual fingers such as the index and thumb) Right-left confusion (an inability to tell whether a hand, foot, or arm of the patient or examiner is on the right or left side of the body) In making this diagnosis, it is important to establish that the finger and left-right naming deficits are not part of more generalized anomia and that the patient is not otherwise aphasic. When Gerstmann’s syndrome arises acutely and in isolation , it is commonly associated with damage to the inferior parietal lobule (especially the angular gyrus ) in the left hemisphere.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B, and D are features of Gerstmann syndrome.

Extraedge:

Semantic PPA Characterized by preserved fluency and syntax (word order) but poor single-word comprehension and profound two-way naming impairments . This kind of aphasia is not seen with CVAs. It differs from Wernicke’s aphasia or posterior transcortical aphasia because speech is usually informative and repetition is intact in semantic PPA. Comprehension of sentences is relatively preserved if the meaning is not too dependent on words that fail to be understood, allowing the patient to surmise the gist of the conversation through contextual cues. Such patients may appear unimpaired in the course of casual small talk but become puzzled upon encountering an undecipherable word such as “pumpkin” or “umbrella.”

questions.text: A speech assessment of a 48-year-old female revealed preserved comprehension but frequent word-finding pauses, spontaneous speech simplification, and anomia. Repetition is usually impaired. MRI brain showed atrophy of the temporoparietal junction. What is the likely diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: Mixed type of primary progressive aphasia

questions.explanation:
Solution:

logopenic primary progressive aphasia Preserved comprehension , impaired Repetition with frequent word-finding pauses and MRI brain showing atrophy of temporoparietal junction all these points towards a diagnosis of Logopenic primary progressive aphasia

Highyeild:

Logopenic primary progressive aphasia- Preserved syntax and comprehension but frequent and severe word-finding pauses, anomia, circumlocutions, and simplifications during spontaneous speech. Repetition is usually impaired. Peak atrophy sites - Temporoparietal junction Posterior temporal lobe partially overlapping with the traditional location of Wernicke’s area. However, the comprehension impairment of Wernicke’s aphasia is absent probably because the underlying deep white matter , frequently damaged by CVAs , remains relatively intact in PPA. The repetition impairment suggests that parts of Wernicke’s area are critical for phonological loop functionality . In contrast to Broca’s aphasia or agrammatic PPA , the interruption of fluency is variable so speech may appear entirely normal if the patient is allowed to engage in small talk. Logopenic PPA resembles anomic aphasia but usually has longer and more frequent word-finding pauses. When repetition is impaired, the aphasia resembles the conduction aphasia. Of all PPA subtypes, this is the one most commonly associated with the pathology of Alzheimer’s Disease , but Frontotemporal dementia (FTD ) can also be the cause.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Semantic primary progressive aphasia will have poor single word comprehension, Comprehension of sentences is relatively preserved if the meaning is not too dependent on words that fail to be understood . Option: B. Agrammatic primary progressive aphasia- The agrammatic variant is characterized by consistently low fluency and impaired grammar but intact word comprehension. Option: D. Mixed type of primary progressive aphasia -where grammar, fluency, and word comprehension is jointly impaired.

Extraedge:

Primary progressive aphasia (PPA) A diagnosis of a primary progressive aphasia (PPA) is justified only if the language disorder (i.e., aphasia) arises in relative isolation , becomes the primary concern that brings the patient to medical attention , and remains the most salient deficit for 1–2 years. The impairments of language in primary progressive aphasia (PPA) have slightly different patterns from those seen in CVA-caused aphasias. For example, the full syndrome of Wernicke’s aphasia is almost never seen in PPA, confirming the view that sentence comprehension and word comprehension are controlled by different regions of the language network. Three major subtypes of PPA can be recognized. 1)Semantic PPA- preserved fluency and syntax (word order) poor single-word comprehension profound two-way naming impairments Neuronal loss- left anterior temporal lobe Resembles- Wernicke’s aphasia or posterior transcortical aphasia speech is usually informative and repetition is intact in semantic PPA while Wernicke's has ‘jargon speech’. 2)Agrammatic PPA- consistently low fluency impaired grammar but intact word comprehension. Neuronal loss- left inferior frontal gyrus Resembles- Broca’s aphasia or anterior transcortical aphasia But Agrammatic PPA usually lacks the right hemiparesis or dysarthria 3)Logopenic PPA- preserved syntax and comprehension frequent and severe word-finding pauses, anomia, circumlocutions, and simplifications during spontaneous speech. Repetition is usually impaired. Neuronal loss- Temporoparietal junction Posterior temporal lobe Resembles- Anomic aphasia but Logopenic PPA usually has longer and more frequent word-finding pauses.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with acute CVA presented with comprehension and repetition impaired for the spoken language but can understand and express in written language, naming, and fluency is normal. What is the most common site of involvement?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Superior temporal gyrus Impaired comprehension and repetition for the spoken language but can understand and express in written language and intact naming and fluency in acute CVA(Most common cause ) case suggest Pure word deafness .

Highyeild:

Pure word deafness- The most common causes are either Bilateral left-sided MCA affecting the superior temporal gyrus . The net effect of the underlying lesion is to interrupt the flow of information from the auditory association cortex to the language network. Patients have no difficulty understanding written language and can express themselves well in spoken or written language. Interpreting and reacting to environmental sounds if the primary auditory cortex and auditory association areas of the right hemisphere are spared. Because auditory information can not be conveyed to the language network, It cannot be decoded into neural word representations, and the patient reacts to speech as if it were in an alien tongue that cannot be deciphered. Patients cannot repeat spoken language but have no difficulty naming objects. In time, patients with pure word deafness teach themselves lipreading and may appear to have improved. There may be no additional neurologic findings, but agitated paranoid reactions are common in the acute stages. Cerebrovascular lesions are the most common cause.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Inferior temporal gyrus -In anomic aphasia , a lesion can occur in the middle and inferior temporal gyrus of the left hemisphere. Option: C. Inferior frontal gyrus -lesion in the Inferior frontal gyrus and surrounding perisylvian and insular cortex may lead to Broca's aphasia. Option: D. Dorsal perisylvian region- The involvement of the dorsal perisylvian region and temporoparietal region may lead to conduction aphasia.
